description: From Middle English by, bi, from Old English bī (“by; near; around”), from Proto-West Germanic *bī, from Proto-Germanic *bi (“near; by; around; about”), from  Proto-Indo-European *h₁epi.

Cognate with West Frisian by (“by; near”), Afrikaans by (“at; by; near”), Saterland Frisian bie (“near; by”), Dutch bij (“near; by”), German Low German bi (“by; near; at”), German bei (“by; near; at”).

entries.meaning: Out of the way, off to one side.
examples: a by path, a by room

entries.meaning: Subsidiary, incidental.
examples: by catch, a by issue

entries.meaning: Along a path which runs past the speaker.
examples: I watched as it passed by.

entries.meaning: In the vicinity, near.
examples: There was a shepherd close by.

entries.meaning: To or at a place, as a residence or place of business.
examples: I'll stop by on my way home from work.
We're right near the lifeguard station. Come by before you leave.

entries.meaning: Aside, away.
examples: The women spent much time after harvest putting jams by for winter and spring.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of bye.
Near or next to.
examples: The mailbox is by the bus stop.

entries.meaning: From one side of something to the other, passing close by; past.
examples: The stream runs by our back door.
He ran straight by me.

entries.meaning: Not later than (the given time); not later than the end of (the given time interval).
examples: Be back by ten o'clock!.
We'll find someone by the end of March.
We will send it by the first week of July.

definitionGroups.group: Indicates the person or thing that does or causes something: Through the action or presence of.

entries.meaning: Following a passive verb.
examples: The matter was decided by the chairman.
The boat was swamped by the water.
He was protected by his body armour.

entries.meaning: Following a noun.
examples: There was a call by the unions for a 30% pay rise.

entries.meaning: (not in common modern use) Following an adjective.
examples: I was aghast by what I saw.

entries.meaning: Indicates the creator of a work: Existing through the authorship etc. of.
examples: There are many well-known plays by William Shakespeare

entries.meaning: Indicates a means of achieving something: Involving/using the means of.
examples: I avoided the guards by moving only when they weren't looking.
By Pythagoras' theorem, we can calculate the length of the hippopotamus.
We went by bus.
I discovered it by chance.
By 'maybe' she means 'no'.
The electricity was cut off, so we had to read by candlelight.

definitionGroups.group: Indicates an authority according to which something is done.

entries.meaning: Invokes an authority in an oath.
examples: By Jove! I think she's got it!
By all that is holy, I'll put an end to this.

entries.meaning: Indicates a means of classification or organisation.
examples: I sorted the items by category.
Table 1 shows details of our employees broken down by sex and age.

entries.meaning: Indicates the amount of change, difference or discrepancy
examples: Our stock is up by ten percent.
His date of birth was wrong by ten years.

entries.meaning: In the formulae X by X and by Xs, indicates a steady progression, one X after another.
examples: We went through the book page by page.
We crawled forward by inches.

entries.meaning: (with the) Acted on in units of the specified size or measure. (Sometimes hyperbolically)
examples: sold by the yard; cheaper if bought by the gross
He drinks brandy by the bucketful!

entries.meaning: per; with or in proportion to each.
examples: His health was deteriorating by the day.
The pickers are paid by the bushel.

entries.meaning: Indicates a referenced source: According to.
examples: He cheated by his own admission.
By my reckoning, we should be nearly there.

entries.meaning: Used to separate dimensions when describing the size of something.
examples: It is easy to invert a 2-by-2 matrix.
The room was about 4 foot by 6 foot.
The bricks used to build the wall measured 10 by 20 by 30 cm.

entries.meaning: (horse breeding) Designates a horse's male parent (sire); cf. out of.
examples: She's a lovely little filly, by Big Lad, out of Damsel in Distress.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Yeshivish) At, with, among
examples: Are you eating by Rabbi Fischer? (at the house of)
By Chabad, it's different. (with, among)
